title: After Nearly Seven Years Held Captive by Boko Haram, a Chibok Girl Manages to Escape
sub_head: Officials say young woman was in group liberated from jihadist kidnappers by military offensive
body:
At least one of the more than 100 young women still missing after their abduction by Islamist militant group Boko Haram in the Nigerian town of Chibok almost seven years ago managed to escape her captors this week, according to family members and local officials.
Halima Ali Maiyanga told her family in a phone call Thursday that she was one of hundreds of captives who were able to flee amid a Nigerian military offensive against Boko Haram fighters in the Sambisa Forest in the country’s northeast.
The Chibok Association, formed after 276 girls were kidnapped from their high school in the town of Chibok in 2014, said several others had also won their freedom during the army’s push. More than 100 of thems were freed in 2016 and 2017 after a ransom payment and the release of some Boko Haram fighters by the government.
“Halima was in tears. She told us she was with the military and needed some clothes because she had nothing,” her brother Muhammad Maiyanga said. “We never thought we’d see her again.”
Ms. Maiyanga, now 22 years old, was 15 when she was kidnapped on the night before her year-end exams. Her older sister Maryam Ali Maiyanga managed to escape in 2017 along with an infant son born after her forced marriage to a jihadist fighter.
